20101221220634.000|20101221220637.000|TR0|
20101221220637.000|20101221220639.000|TR0|We'll stand by for the final vote tomorrow.
20101221220639.000|20101221220641.000|TR0|
20101221220641.000|20101221220644.000|TR0|The new START Treaty would reduce the 
20101221220644.000|20101221220646.000|TR0|nuclear arsenals of both of the United 
20101221220646.000|20101221220648.000|TR0|States and Russia, cutting the maximum 
20101221220648.000|20101221220651.000|TR0|number of strategic warheads by about a 
20101221220651.000|20101221220653.000|TR0|third.  The 10 year pact includes a 
20101221220653.000|20101221220655.000|TR0|process for each nation to check up on the 
20101221220655.000|20101221220658.000|TR0|other, including on site nuclear 
20101221220658.000|20101221220700.000|TR0|inspections.  It needs 67 votes to be 
20101221220700.000|20101221220702.000|TR0|ratified by the United States Senate.
20101221220702.000|20101221220705.000|TR0|
20101221220705.000|20101221220707.000|TR0|Now, the United States by the numbers.  
20101221220707.000|20101221220709.000|TR0|There are over 308 million people in the 
20101221220709.000|20101221220712.000|TR0|country right now, according to a 2010 
20101221220712.000|20101221220714.000|TR0|Census report released today.  The 
20101221220714.000|20101221220716.000|TR0|population grew in Western and Southern 
20101221220716.000|20101221220719.000|TR0|states -- Republican leaning areas that 
20101221220719.000|20101221220721.000|TR0|will gain seats in Congress. These eight 
20101221220721.000|20101221220723.000|TR0|states will get additional members in the 
20101221220723.000|20101221220726.000|TR0|U.S. House -- Arizona, Florida, Georgia, 
20101221220726.000|20101221220728.000|TR0|Nevada, South Carolina, Texas, Utah and 
20101221220728.000|20101221220730.000|TR0|Washington.  Ten states will lose House 
20101221220730.000|20101221220733.000|TR0|members -- Illinois, Iowa, Louisiana, 
20101221220733.000|20101221220735.000|TR0|Massachusetts, Michigan, Missouri, New 
20101221220735.000|20101221220737.000|TR0|Jersey, New York, Ohio and Pennsylvania.  
20101221220737.000|20101221220740.000|TR0|President Obama won all but two of those 
20101221220740.000|20101221220742.000|TR0|states back in 2008.
20101221220742.000|20101221220744.000|TR0|

20101221220801.000|20101221220803.000|TR0|DAN LOTHIAN, CNN WHITE HOUSE 
20101221220803.000|20101221220805.000|TR0|CORRESPONDENT:  Well, White House 
20101221220805.000|20101221220808.000|TR0|spokesman, Robert Gibbs, saying today that 
20101221220808.000|20101221220810.000|TR0|he doesn't think that this will have a 
20101221220810.000|20101221220812.000|TR0|huge practical impact.  Yes, under these 
20101221220812.000|20101221220815.000|TR0|new Census numbers, the president would 
20101221220815.000|20101221220817.000|TR0|get fewer electoral votes in 2012.  But if 
20101221220817.000|20101221220819.000|TR0|you look at the wide margin of victory 
20101221220819.000|20101221220822.000|TR0|that the president had in 2008, this would 
20101221220822.000|20101221220824.000|TR0|not have been a factor at all.  What this 
20101221220824.000|20101221220826.000|TR0|would have come into play would have been 
20101221220826.000|20101221220829.000|TR0|in like in 2000, when the race was much 
20101221220829.000|20101221220831.000|TR0|tighter.     The bottom line, though, is 
20101221220831.000|20101221220833.000|TR0|what we're talking about here, is the 2012 
20101221220833.000|20101221220836.000|TR0|campaign, which the president has not 
20101221220836.000|20101221220838.000|TR0|formally said that he is running, although 
20101221220838.000|20101221220840.000|TR0|all signs are there that he will.  And 
20101221220840.000|20101221220843.000|TR0|most experts believe that it won't be the 
20101221220843.000|20101221220845.000|TR0|Census that will be driving the voters at 
20101221220845.000|20101221220847.000|TR0|that time, that it really will be the 
20101221220847.000|20101221220850.000|TR0|economy, the economic recovery -- how far 
20101221220850.000|20101221220852.000|TR0|that has come along, how people are 
20101221220852.000|20101221220854.000|TR0|feeling about their economic situations.  
20101221220854.000|20101221220857.000|TR0|That will be the driver when they head to 
20101221220857.000|20101221220859.000|TR0|the polls, not the Census numbers -- Wolf.

20101221220946.000|20101221220948.000|TR0|Caucus, discussing various issues, 
20101221220948.000|20101221220950.000|TR0|including the failure of the DREAM Act, 
20101221220950.000|20101221220953.000|TR0|which, of course, would have provided a 
20101221220953.000|20101221220955.000|TR0|pathway for citizenship for those younger, 
20101221220955.000|20101221220957.000|TR0|illegal immigrants if they were to join 
20101221220957.000|20101221221000.000|TR0|the military or went to college.

20101221221002.000|20101221221004.000|TR0|It was a big disappointment for this White 
20101221221004.000|20101221221007.000|TR0|House, the president talking with those 
20101221221007.000|20101221221009.000|TR0|members about the way forward in the next 
20101221221009.000|20101221221011.000|TR0|session. But, of course, some challenges 
20101221221011.000|20101221221014.000|TR0|there because Republicans will have the -- 
20101221221014.000|20101221221016.000|TR0|the leadership in the House.  And this is 
20101221221016.000|20101221221018.000|TR0|something the Republicans have been

20101221221953.000|20101221221955.000|TR0|they don't let you have access.  I didn't

20101221222002.000|20101221222005.000|TR0|was about it.

20101221222009.000|20101221222012.000|TR0|I could make calls to the United States at 
20101221222012.000|20101221222014.000|TR0|about $10 a minute; I could not receive 
20101221222014.000|20101221222016.000|TR0|calls from the United States.
20101221222016.000|20101221222019.000|TR0|
20101221222019.000|20101221222021.000|TR0|And we always had North Korean officials 
20101221222021.000|20101221222023.000|TR0|who were with us watching all the time, 
20101221222023.000|20101221222026.000|TR0|and I stress, all of the time.
20101221222026.000|20101221222028.000|TR0|
20101221222028.000|20101221222030.000|TR0|So it's a strange environment.  But they 
20101221222030.000|20101221222033.000|TR0|treated me with respect. They were nice, 
20101221222033.000|20101221222035.000|TR0|they spoke English.  I never felt 
20101221222035.000|20101221222037.000|TR0|intimidated or worried about my personal 
20101221222037.000|20101221222040.000|TR0|safety.  I was worried about a war

20101221225123.000|20101221225125.000|TR0|companies don't interfere with your 
20101221225125.000|20101221225127.000|TR0|Internet access. Controversial new rules 
20101221225127.000|20101221225130.000|TR0|were approved today.
20101221225130.000|20101221225132.000|TR0|
20101221225132.000|20101221225134.000|TR0|CNN's Martin Savidge is here to explain

20101221225137.000|20101221225139.000|TR0|
20101221225139.000|20101221225141.000|TR0|What's going on, Marty?
20101221225141.000|20101221225144.000|TR0|
20101221225144.000|20101221225146.000|TR0|MARTIN SAVIDGE, CNN CORRESPONDENT:  Well, 
20101221225146.000|20101221225148.000|TR0|hello, Wolf.
20101221225148.000|20101221225151.000|TR0|
20101221225151.000|20101221225153.000|TR0|The Federal Communications Commission 
20101221225153.000|20101221225155.000|TR0|established what you could say are some 
20101221225155.000|20101221225158.000|TR0|basic rules of the road for that 
20101221225158.000|20101221225200.000|TR0|information superhighway otherwise known 
20101221225200.000|20101221225202.000|TR0|as the high-speed Internet.  And a lot of 
20101221225202.000|20101221225205.000|TR0|people are not happy with them.
20101221225205.000|20101221225207.000|TR0|
20101221225207.000|20101221225209.000|TR0|(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)
20101221225209.000|20101221225212.000|TR0|
20101221225212.000|20101221225214.000|TR0|SAVIDGE (voice-over):  The so-called net 
20101221225214.000|20101221225216.000|TR0|neutrality rules have the first broad 
20101221225216.000|20101221225219.000|TR0|regulations of broadband and have received 
20101221225219.000|20101221225221.000|TR0|strong support from Democrats, online 
20101221225221.000|20101221225223.000|TR0|activists, and some large Internet 
20101221225223.000|20101221225226.000|TR0|companies.  "We have an historic 
20101221225226.000|20101221225228.000|TR0|opportunity to make sure this dynamic 
20101221225228.000|20101221225230.000|TR0|Internet technology reaches its full 
20101221225230.000|20101221225233.000|TR0|potential to create opportunity for every 
20101221225233.000|20101221225235.000|TR0|citizen," said the chairman of the FCC, a 
20101221225235.000|20101221225237.000|TR0|Democrat.
20101221225237.000|20101221225240.000|TR0|
20101221225240.000|20101221225242.000|TR0|The goal, say backers, is to make sure 
20101221225242.000|20101221225244.000|TR0|powerful Internet service providers don't 
20101221225244.000|20101221225247.000|TR0|give preferential treatment to their own 
20101221225247.000|20101221225249.000|TR0|content or that of wealthy partners, while 
20101221225249.000|20101221225251.000|TR0|denying or slowing access to competitors.  
20101221225251.000|20101221225254.000|TR0|Think how Comcast, which is buying NBC, 
20101221225254.000|20101221225256.000|TR0|might -- and I underline might -- want to 
20101221225256.000|20101221225258.000|TR0|slow down your access to Netflix while 
20101221225258.000|20101221225301.000|TR0|speeding up your ability to get NBC 
20101221225301.000|20101221225303.000|TR0|programming.
20101221225303.000|20101221225305.000|TR0|
20101221225305.000|20101221225308.000|TR0|But Comcast doesn't do that, which is why 
20101221225308.000|20101221225310.000|TR0|many Republicans and free market advocates 
20101221225310.000|20101221225312.000|TR0|say regulation isn't needed.
20101221225312.000|20101221225315.000|TR0|
20101221225315.000|20101221225317.000|TR0|SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY), MINORITY 
20101221225317.000|20101221225319.000|TR0|LEADER:  Today, the Obama administration, 
20101221225319.000|20101221225322.000|TR0|which has already nationalized health 
20101221225322.000|20101221225324.000|TR0|care, the auto industry, insurance 
20101221225324.000|20101221225326.000|TR0|companies, banks, and student loans, will 
20101221225326.000|20101221225329.000|TR0|move forward with what could be the first 
20101221225329.000|20101221225331.000|TR0|step in controlling how Americans use the 
20101221225331.000|20101221225333.000|TR0|Internet.
20101221225333.000|20101221225336.000|TR0|
20101221225336.000|20101221225338.000|TR0|SAVIDGE:  Opponents like Republican FCC 
20101221225338.000|20101221225340.000|TR0|Commissioner Robert McDowell say the new 
20101221225340.000|20101221225343.000|TR0|rules won't protect, but instead hurt the 
20101221225343.000|20101221225345.000|TR0|Internet by, as he put it, "inhibiting 
20101221225345.000|20101221225347.000|TR0|capital investment, deterring innovation, 
20101221225347.000|20101221225350.000|TR0|raising operating costs, and ultimately

20101221225352.000|20101221225354.000|TR0|
20101221225354.000|20101221225357.000|TR0|CRAIG AARON, FREEPRESS.NET:  I think 
20101221225357.000|20101221225359.000|TR0|today's vote is really a disappointment.

20101221225401.000|20101221225404.000|TR0|SAVIDGE:  Craig Aaron of FreePress.net
